elements.text: Ready, gentlemen? Take the strain, and heave! eave!
We... are... heaving.
Come on, Robert, put some effort into it.
All right, all right. Halim, Ishag, break up. Break up!
It's not moved, Mister Carter.
This door has been sealed for nigh on three thousand years, Miss Templeton.
So, it's going to take a bit of shifting.
I didn't bring you out here simply to observe, Mister Charles.
Oh, of course not. I never imagined field study would be quite so hands-on, that's all.
We go again, gentlemen, after three. One, two, three! Heave!
I just hope this... Userhat fellow is worth... breaking our backs for.
The tomb of an overseer of the Fields of Amun ought to contain many interesting artefacts, Mister Charles.
Maybe even a... mummy or two?
I say, it's moving.
Come on, keep at it! Heave!
Well, I just hope there isn't a curse on it. Wouldn't want to bring a plague of locusts down upon us all.
No such things as curses. Heave!
No, wait. It's crumbling.
Thud.
Is everyone all right?
Whispering voices
I say, do you hear something? Most peculiar. All of a sudden it was as though a... a whatsit had walked over your, your...
Your grave?
Oh! Jane, you startled me.
A minor earth tremor, that's all, caused by the displacement of ancient air.
Yes. I'm sure it was.
Pass me that lantern, Miss Templeton. Let's see what we've got here, shall we?
Tardis engines making a nasty noise.
What's happening? Doctor?
A spot of Time disruption. Oh!
Yeah? Which means?
Er, we're being wrenched out of the Vortex. Hold onto your hat, Mister Hex.
I haven't got a hat!
Well, hold onto his!
Oh, this is a rather tricky manoeuvre.
It's all right. I've got it.
Eh?
His hat.
Doctor, you okay?
My fingertips are a little singed, that's all.
You what?
Hit the button, would you?
Hit - wh-what?
Hit the button, Ace. Hit the button .
Which one?
The green one.
Oh, you only had to say.
The Tardis materialises.
Oh well, that seems to have put us on an even keel.
Whispering voices.
Hey, do you hear that?
Hear what, Mister Hex?
Remember Thoth? I dunno. Something like that.
Hearing voices now, are we?
Not in a bad way, all right?
Residual time echo, perhaps, conveyed through the Tardis's telepathic circuits.
But why would it target me?
Perhaps it fancied you.
Oh, behave. So where are we, anyway?
Egypt. Thebes, to be exact. The year 1902.
And is this where the time disruption came from?
Let's find out.
Tardis doors open.
Mister Hex. My hat, if you please.
How goes it, Mister Charles?
With the collapsed roof and the flood damage, the workmen cannot proceed any further until they've finished shoring things up.
Patience. The occupant of this tomb has lain here for three thousand years. It's only courteous to take our time.
Mister Carter. I say, Mister Carter.
Hello. Jane looks excited.
What have you got there, my dear?
It's magnificent. Miraculously preserved.
What is it?
Oh, Robert.
Consider this a test, Mister Charles. Let's see how much you've learned under my tutelage.
Oh. Right. Gosh. Er, a wooden box, half cubit square. Oh. I'm, I'm no good with the er... hieroglyphics, I'm afraid.
But look inside.
It's all right, Mister Charles.
Would you believe it? Toy soldiers.
Mister Charles! Enlighten him, Jane.
They’re shabti figures, to act as servants in the afterlife.
Absolutely. The more shabti a fellow had, the higher his status.
Our chap had only forty five. The Egyptian Kings had hundreds.
Quite so.
I'll put the box in the supply tent, shall I?
Along with the rest of the artefacts.
Very good, sir.
And be sure to keep them in the shade... Oh no!
Hiya!
Do you know those people, sir?
Sightseers. I'm sorry, this area is out of bounds to civilians.
Quite right. The occupant of this tomb has lain here for three thousand years.
The last thing he needs is a bunch of tourists rifling through his stuff.
Who are you people? I can permit no access without the proper authorisation.
And as the Chief Inspector of Antiquities, you, Mister Carter, are the man to grant those authorisations.
Well, yes, I am, but the point is...
Carter? Isn't he the guy who...?
(sotto) Yeah, just let the Doctor do the talking.
I'm the Doctor, and - and these are my students, Ace and Hex. I'm a colleague of Professor Petrie's from University College.
He's never mentioned you.
Students, you say? Me too.
They can be something of a burden. But if all else fails I find them terribly good at making tea.
I... Of course. Robert, if you could...?
Oh, well, yes. I Suppose so.
Splendid. Ace, go with him.
Yeah, but Hex makes a much better cuppa.
So you need the practice. Besides, I'm sure Robert won't mind filling you in on all Mister Carter has unearthed thus far.
(sigh) Okay.
This way, Miss. Mind the roof debris.
Yeah, I can manage.
See ya.
Now, Mister Carter, this tomb of yours. We're on the far side of the East Valley. So this must be KV 45, correct?
I beg your pardon?
(sotto) Oh. Oh, of course, no. Of course, you don't call it that yet. (normal) Never mind. Just lead the way.
Er - yes. Halim? Ishaq? More lights here. Chop-chop. (leaves)
Doctor, this is Howard Carter, right? You know, the fella who found Tutankhamen's tomb?
(sotto) Yes. But not for another twenty years, so don't mention it. Just stay close and keep your senses attuned for anything unusual.
Like what?
Sounds. Vibrations. If whatever drew us here latched onto you in the Tardis, you might be particularly sensitive to its effects.
Okay, Doctor. And don't worry. If a six foot mummy suddenly starts crashing through the crypt, I'll let you know loudly.
Water's on the boil. I'm afraid the local brew is rather noxious.
I'm sure I've had worse. So whose tomb is it?
Userhat, Mister Carter thinks. A servant of Amun.
Who's that? Some Pharaoh?
Oh. Now, I know this. Amun, you see, was one of the, the principal Egyptian Gods known as the Hidden One, or er, the Mysterious...
The Mysterious of Form.
Oh! Jane. I wish you wouldn't keep popping up like that.
It was said that Amun’s true identity and appearance could never be revealed, and that he was able to resurrect himself by shedding his skin.
Reminds me of a friend of mine.
Really?
I'm Ace, by the way.
Curious name.
I'm a curious girl.
Miss Ace is a student like us. She's with a colleague of Professor Petrie's. A doctor. I didn't catch his name.
And has your Doctor observed anything interesting?
Everything's interesting to the Doctor. You'd be amazed what he unearths sometimes.
Sounds like a useful fellow to have around, eh Jane?
Perhaps.
Tea's up.
Oh - dash it, I've forgotten the sugar. I'll just pop and get some from the supply tent. Leave you two to... get acquainted. Good-o.
These mummies don't half give me the creeps.
They're just husks wrapped in bandages, Hex. They can’t hurt you.

Yeah, but they were people once. It’s weird to think we could pop back and visit them in the Tardis if we wanted. Doesn't that ever freak ya out, Doctor, knowing you could choose someone, anyone, and go to the christening, wedding and funeral all on the same day?
I don't think about it.
If I were you, I'd think about it all the time.
Mister Carter? Hello?
Yes? Yes. Sorry. Idiot workmen were throwing out potsherds.
Ah. I presume that various artefacts have already been removed from the tomb?
Some, yes. Canopic jars, a shabti box...
A what?
A wooden box, decorated with hieroglyphics. It contains a number of painted figures known as shabti. Where is this box now?
Well, in the supply tent.
Whispering voice.
Who's that?
I beg your pardon?
Mister Hex?
I... I thought I heard something. Just, just for a moment.
Hello? Who's that? Oh. I could have sworn... I say. If there is anyone here, you'd best be off,
because Mister Carter was very clear. If he finds anyone else has been at the cheese...
Whispering voices.
What the devil...? (screams)
Did you hear that? Jane?
I didn't hear anything.
Shh. Listen.
I still don't hear anything.
Exactly. All the noise outside has stopped.
Oh, don't tell me those workmen have downed tools again. Good grief.
There's just sand and sky.
But... the dig, it's gone.
Everything's gone.
The workmen, the tents. How can they have...?
I don't know. But I'm going to find out. No. No sign. Ah! The sun! It's... it's burning me!
Get back inside, quick. Quick!
Ow! Ah! I'm blistering. Look at my hands. Just look!
I'll fetch some water. A cloth, something.
Just hurry up! Oh, God. You'd need Factor Five Million out there. Why is it so hot?
Here. Wrap it around your hands.
Yeah, how?
Oh, sorry. Let me help.
Thanks. I'll tell you what. No way should the sun be that red colour. Like there's something wrong with...
The ozone layer. Yes.
I'm sorry, did you just say...?
Can you smell something? Something like...
Burning. Oh... I've got a bad feeling about this.
The tent - it's catching fire!
We've been projected forward in time, I think. You, me, the tent we're sat in. To a point where there’s no escape from the sun’s radiation.
What do we do?
Er... blanket. We cover ourselves with blankets.
Then what?
We make a run for it. And we pray that whenever it is we are, no one's filled in this tomb of yours.
In here, Doctor.
Thank you, Mister Carter.
Confounded flies! If they've got at the provisions...
I don't think so, Mister Carter.
Oh, hey.
Good God. Is that... a man?
Hex?
Yeah. Stone dead. Dead for years. Centuries, in fact.
One moment. Those clothes. Oxfords, and a waistcoat. That's...
Robert Charles, yes. He's been caught on the outside edge of a localised time field, and the epicentre was... Ah.
What is it? Doctor?
Mister Carter, what used to be in that spot there?
Why, the kitchen tent. It... it's vanished.
Doctor, you sent Ace to make the tea.
I know. What happened to that shabti box, Mister Carter?
Well, I don't know.
Here, Doctor. Someone's taken the figures out.
Oh, but this is vandalism!
Count them, Hex.
I shall have to inform the gendarmerie. I regret, Doctor, that I must also insist you present to me your credentials.
I'm a Time Lord, Mister Carter. I came here on the trail of a disturbance in Space-Time.
Space-Time?
Yes. How many figures were there in that box?
Ev... forty-five. Why?
Hex?
Forty two, forty three, forty four.
One is missing. I wonder why.
Jane, lose the satchel. It's weighing you down.
Just run.
The tomb entrance. It’s still here.
That's the blankets gone.
Only trouble is... Oh! Oh! We're locked out!
The sun's still climbing. We won’t be shaded here for long. And then...
Crispy fried Ace. Oh!
Shh! Did you hear...?
Halt!
Your presence is unauthorised.
Don't panic. It's just a machine.
Just?
Security droid, I reckon.
Silence. You may not speak unless asked a direct question.
Well, that's me told.
If you do not comply I am authorised to neutralise you under Article 1045 of the Unified States Of Africa Convention.
Neutralise? How?
Zap, boom.
Oh!
That's how.
I... still can't believe it. Whatever shall I tell Lord Charles, about Robert?
Howard, mate, chances are we'll be next if the Doctor can't suss out what’s causing this...
Time disruption?
Precisely. Tell me, Mister Carter, can you translate the hieroglyphics on this box?
Yes, I expect so.
Then?
Well, if you think it will help. Yes. Er... it's the story of how Geb - the sky - and Nut - the earth argued...
Argued with Ra the sun, which unbalanced the world’s orbit. Yes. Oh, sorry. Do go on.
Er... Ra was tricked into changing his position in the sky by Thoth, the diva of Time and magic, which...
Remember Thoth?
Quiet.
Which altered the angle of the Earth in relation to the sun. I suppose ancient calendars do show a time when the sun rose and set in a different place from now.
Then the myth relates to a shift in the Earth’s axial rotation.
Er - if you say so.
What are you getting at, Doctor?
I'm not sure.
Screams outside.
What the blazes is happening now?
Careful, Mister Carter.
I'm only taking a look.
What is that!
Something growls.
It's some sort of hyena, or bear.
Only massive!
Halim? Halim, watch out!
Scream.
Great. Now it's seen us.
Fascinating. A Creodont. The largest mammalian predator ever to walk the planet.
I've never heard of it.
I'm not surprised. It's been extinct for twenty million years.
Spare us the David Attenborough bit, you two. Run!
Jane, are you all right?
Fine.
Sensors indicate that you are not equipped with authorisation chips.
Er, sorry, must have left them at home.
Ace, don't antagonise it.
(sotto) It's a robot. It can't get antagonised.
Silence! Unauthorised individuals in the East Valley zone are deemed to be heritage raiders.
We're tourists.
That is no defence. Heritage raiders are subject to the ultimate jurisdiction. Prepare to be neutralised.
Wait. I have something in my satchel. Something to prove our credentials.
You have?
You have?
It... it's an artefact. I think you'll find it interesting.
If you attempt to deceive me you will be neutralised under Article...
Yeah, yeah, we've heard all that, tin-head. What are you playing at, Jane?
You'll see. Hold this, will you?
A key?
A key.
Why do you delay?
Here it is.
I do not recognise this object.
It's a shabti figure.
Do what?
A heritage artefact. You are heritage raiders. Neutralise. Neutralise.
Duck. (boom) Jane.
I'm all right. I think. The shabti.
Heritage raiders not neutralised. Preparing to neutralise.
It's here, all right?
The key. Pass the key into the figure’s mouth.
But there's no slot or anything.
Just do it.
Yeah, okay.
Neutralise, neutralise!
A Tardis materialises.
But that's...
Another heritage object!
A Tardis, tin-head. Ace, get in.
The Doctor's Tardis. But...
The Doctor’s? No. No, it's mine. Get in.
Heritage raiders escaping.
Door opens.
You betcha!
Door closes.
Halt. Halt!
Growling.
Are we safe in here?
That creature's too big to get through the doorway.
For now, but the stone is old and brittle. It won't hold forever.
Then we've had it. We're like Happy Meals in a box.
Don't be pessimistic, Hex. I'll think of something.
Well, you'd better think quickly, Doctor. It's getting through!
You're a time traveller?
Well, duh.
I'm sorry. Had I realised soonet...
What's going on, Jane?
Isn't it obvious? We're escaping.
You know what I mean. You're from Gallifrey. You're a Time Lord.
Well, a trainee. Though I suspect I've missed my graduation ceremony by now, relatively speaking.
So what's the story?
Let's concentrate on getting out of here first, shall we?
Unhappy Tardis engines.
It's breaking through.
Hey! Big boy! Get a face-full of this!
What do you think you're doing?
Don't just stand there, mate. Find some more stuff to chuck at it.
These are valuable potsherds.
It's no use, Hex. We'll have to go further back into the tomb and squeeze into the smallest space we can find.
What good would that do, Doctor? The beast will still seek us out eventually.
The temporal field is unstable. The Creodont would vanish as suddenly as it appeared. It's simply a matter of Time.
It's time we don't have, Doctor. It's going to break through any second.
I say.
A Tardis materialises.
What's that noise?
It's the Tardis. How did you swing that one, Doctor ?
This has nothing to do with me.
Door opens.
Doctor. Hex.
Ace. A timely intervention.
Where did you spring from?
Do you really want an explanation right now?
Good point. Tell us inside.
This way, Mister Carter.
Gosh. This is extraordinary.
Yeah. And it's about to get a whole lot weirder.
Time for that later.
Jane, doors.
Doors close.
Don't worry. It can't get inside. I hope.
Remember Thoth, the diva of time and magic.
Hey. That's...
Observe the scanner, Mister Hex.
The, the creature is... fading from view?
Just like the Doctor said it would. All right! So, how did you two get to fly this thing? I thought only the Doctor could do that...
This isn’t my Tardis.
It's Jane’s.
Yeah, but it looks just like yours.
That's because it's Time-linked itself to mine to stay alive.
What? It's dying?
It should have been put to sleep long ago. Sounds like it’s been suffering for centuries, and now it's become dangerous.
You're wrong, Doctor. I can repair it.
It's beyond repair, Jane.
But I need to repair it. It’s the only way I can get home.
Why don't you tell us who you really are?
I'm a student, like I always said. Year 45. I came to Earth centuries ago, on a field trip.
Ah. Academy History Module 101. Assyrian Cosmic Influence.

Exactly. I had a colleague with me. Antak. There was a freak surge in the Vortex and our Tardis was damaged by a Time spike. We managed to materialise, but we’d lost our time signature. Our route map home.
I'm sorry, I'm not following any of this.
Don't worry about it, Mister C. Just go with the flow.
We tried to integrate ourselves into the local populace, but our arrival was observed. They worshipped us as Gods. They named Antak Amun.
And you were...?
Yes. Thoth.
You should not have got involved.
No. For a while everything was fine, but one year the crops failed. There was an uprising. I escaped into the Sudan. Antak... did not.
And this Tardis?
Antak had set the chameleon circuit to disguise it as a shabti figure. But during the uprising it was lost, stolen.
By Userhat.
I think so, yes. I've spent a dozen lifetimes searching for his tomb. Recently it's been calling to me.
It's been breaking down, decaying with age and neglect.
I followed its trail. I knew it was somewhere here, sealed up in the Valley of the Kings.
It was you, Miss Templeton, who suggested I dig at this site.
Yes.
I took you for a promising student. But you're... nothing of the kind.
So, what do we do now?
Jane?
I can't do it, Doctor.
You have to.
What? What must she do?
Kill her Tardis. That's right, isn't it?
I'm afraid so. By piloting it into the heart of a star.
But what happens to Jane?
Ah, hey. Don't tell me the captain goes down with her ship?
Of course not. I'll track her in my Tardis, materialise my Tardis inside hers, and pull her out a split second before hers is destroyed.
Then what? You'll take me back to Gallifrey, to face the consequences?
Yes. Now, take us to my Tardis.
It dematerialises painfully.
I must confess, I'm still not entirely sure what’s going on.
You're about to travel into space, Mister C. Trip of a lifetime.
My dear friend Professor Petrie often says life is an adventure, Howard, one should grasp it with both hands.
He sounds like a good bloke, this Professor of yours.
He is indeed.
Hush, you two, I'm concentrating.
Swap you. My one's a bit grumpy.
[OC]: Doctor?
Jane's on the scanner, Doctor .
Hello, Jane. All ready to go?
[OC]: As ready as I'll ever be.
Right, Jane. Synchronise coordinates.
[OC]: Coordinates synchronised.
Calibrators online.
[OC]: Online, check.
On my count. One, two, three.
The Tardis dematerialises.
So far, so good.
Now for the tricky bit.
[OC]: What will they do to me, on Gallifrey?
Never mind that now.
[OC]: Antak and I - we set ourselves up as Gods. That's a Class Two intervention, isn't it?
You were only students.
[OC]: The penalty is vaporisation. Even students know that.
There's some interference on the scanner, Doctor.
And should this red light be flashing on the console?
Jane, your temporal stabiliser's slipping.
[OC]: I'm sorry, Doctor.
No, no! No, Jane!
What's happening?
She's running away. Isn't she? Doctor?
I'm losing her! She’s slipping back through Time!
The Cloister Bell tolls.
Doctor, we're getting really close to the Sun.
I can't get a fix on her. She's jumping time tracks quicker than I can keep up.
Doctor, the Sun.
Jane! Listen to me. I can talk to them. It's not like it was in the old days.
[OC]: Too late.
Bang.
We're burning up!
Hang on, Jane. I'm adjusting the temporal drift compensators. I'm right behind you.
[OC]: Too close to the sun now. Remember Thoth. The diva of time and magic. Remember...
Jane. Jane!
She's gone, Doctor. You've got to get us out of here.
I have to save her.
Ace is right, Doctor. It's too late.
The button. Hex, hit the green button.
No, don’t.
The Tardis materialises.
Sorry, but...
Do you know what you've done, Mister Hex? I could have saved her!
I don't believe you could, Doctor.
I'm sorry?
Remember Thoth? Those were Jane's words. I believe... I believe she's already fulfilled her destiny.
What do you mean? Mister C?
Remember Thoth.
It's a story from ancient Egypt. Thoth, the diva of time and magic, tricked Ra, the sun god, into changing his position in the sky.
So Jane slipped back thousands of years...
And crashed her Tardis into the heart of the Sun, yes. But in doing so, she caused a small shift in the Earth's axial rotation. A Class One intervention.
Poor girl.
There's one thing I don't understand. If Jane was Thoth, who told the story in the first place? I mean, who painted the symbols on that box?
I think we can guess.
It was you, wasn't it, Doctor? You went back and told Jane's story.
Not yet, but one day. Who knows?
We can dig up the past, but who can predict the future, eh, Doctor?
Yes, Mister Carter. Who indeed.
Order of Simplicity, by Nick Scovell A Big Finish Productions Dr Who 45" Anniversary Audio Drama, released Nov 2008
Knock on door, door creaks open.
Good morning. Forgive the intrusion. I'm the Doctor, and these are my friends...
Door slammed shut.
Oh.
Some welcome.
Oh, come on, guys. I'm soaking.
Why don't you shout through the letterbox?
Why don't you forget it?
I can't. Er, hello?
CRISP [OC]: What do you want?
A talk with Doctor Verryman.
CRISP [OC]: Impossible.
Oh. Is he not in?
CRISP [OC]: Doctor Verryman is not receiving visitors.
But I have important information for him. To do with the code.
Door opens.
The code?
Yes. I picked it up on my communication channel. I'm certain I can help?
Come in.
Oh, thank you.
At last. I was gonna catch me death if I was stood out in the rain much longer. Brr!
Wimp.
Ah, thank you, Mrs...?
Mrs Crisp. May I take your...?
Umbrella? Yes. Sorry about the dripping.
That's no way to talk about Hex.
Oi.
You love it.
Boots, Ace?
Oh. Yeah. Sorry. Bit muddy, this island of Mentalovonia.
Mendolovinia. It is a little off the beaten track.
I'll say.
But I daresay Doctor Verryman finds it most peaceful here for his work.
That was the reason he came. In here.
Door opens.
You may wait. I shall consult with Doctor Verryman.
You've very kind, Mrs Cr...
Door slammed.
I'm not sure the atmosphere wasn't warmer outside.
Bit frosty, wasn't she?
Efficient and in charge. The perfect housekeeper.
Oh, in which case, do you think she'll make us a cup of tea?
Doubt it. One look from her'd freeze the pot.
Children...
Oh, come on, Doctor. I mean, oil lamps, stone flooring, gas pipes. In what year did you say this was?
The year is 3380. I admit the decor is a little...
Addams Family timeshare?
I was going to say Bleak House.
So, how do you know this Doctor Verryman?
I don't. I've never met him. I've only ever read his books.
Page-turners, are they?
Considering he and his colleagues, including the great Professor Caldeer, are the foremost authorities on bio-engineering in this epoch, they're surprisingly easy to follow.
So Hex would be fine.
Ha-ha-ha.
This island is part of the Sphere of Influence, a planet almost completely devoted to the advancement of knowledge.
Oh, kind of intergalactic Oxbridge, then?
More or less. Verryman was one of its founders.
Was?
I think he's retired now.
So why is he sending out some mysterious code?
Don't tell me. He's a Sudoku bore.
There's more to it than that. A triple-ciphered code on multiple frequencies, with an urgent request to find the solution...
And you're the man to do it?
Well, I am a genius twice over - no, three times. Come on.
Door opens.
Mrs Crisp, she said to wait here.
What's the matter, Hex? (sotto) Scared of the spooky housekeeper?
Maybe. A bit. Oh, go on.
So what do you reckon, Doctor? A good old nose about?
I was thinking more of following it.
Following what?
My nose.
Right. And your nose is pointing us...?
Upstairs, I think. Yes.
Fine. So long as it's not in the basement.
What's wrong with basements?
I hate basements. Bad things happen in basements.
Can you hear that?
What, Hex's burblings?
I mean, feel that. A vibration. Like the ghost of something mechanical.
(sotto) Ghost?
It may be nothing.
You! You're here. You came!
Doctor Verryman, I presume?
Of course. Tell me, er...?
Doctor.
Mmm. Have you solved it? The code?
Well...
Mrs Crisp! Mrs Crisp!
Doctor Verryman, sir.
In the name of the six-chinned sages of Saturn's rings, be a pillar to us all, and pop the kettle on.
At once.
Oh, at last.
Go with her, Hex.
Why?
She took an instant dislike to Ace.
Muddy boots.
Oh, hell.
Mrs Crisp, my young friend Hex would like to help you with the tea things.
If it's not beyond him, follow me. The kitchen's in the basement.
Wh-where?
My friends, I shall die if you don't tell me the solution.
The solution. Yes.
It's not that simple.
Of course it's not that simple. We shall retire to my laboratory. Come.
You heard the man, Ace.
I expect they heard him on Saturn's rings.
(loud) Come!
In, in. Sit yourselves down.
Now, this is more like it. Proper techie stuff.
Don't touch anything.
Do as he says, Ace.
Mmm, what's this then? A hospital scanner?
A what?
It's an inductor, Ace.
Oh. And what's an inductor when it's at home?
It is the future.
The patient is strapped in here, whereupon a series of probes descend from...
The outside, yeah.
Uh-uh. Fingers.
Slapping.
Ow!
To identify the problem and begin treatment. Surgery with energy pulses and gravity manipulation. No scalpels or mess. Very clever stuff. Just a moment.
Er - fingers?
The Doctor is a fellow professional.
Huh! Yeah, right.
These settings make no sense at all. It's as if...
The inductor has been modified. It is no longer intended merely to cure.
I'm not sure I like the sound of this.
I seek to restructure the human brain, suppressing primitive desires and enhancing the intellect. An alchemical transformation from the base to the divine.
More like sublime to the ridiculous.
Er, why is it linked up to the antennas on the roof?
Whatever gave you that idea?
Cables running through the skylights?
And we saw the antennas from the beach. Very good, Ace.
Blimey.
Imagine. If one could broadcast improving pulses across the ether, countless billions would benefit, instantly and without effort.
What? Brain surgery by radio?
Across multiple frequencies. A unilateral operation beamed out across the universe.
Augmenting and extending the mental capacities of the entire human race.
You're nuts.

Shut up. I'm going to ask one more time, and before any of you speak, bear in mind the Ranulph Fiennes Bunker doesn't officially exist, which puts you all in an extremely precarious position. Now, how did you get in here, and who do you work for!

A ghost with a gun?

Claire. Call me Claire. We'll head up to the control centre, I'll explain what I can on the way.

Not the basement.

Don't be scared, Doctor.
Claire. Claire.
Dead. Oh well, so it goes. Goodbye, Doctor. It's been a blast.
[OC]: Doctor, we've got to the switch. Doctor, are you there?
Give me that. Switch? What switch? What are you talking about?
The switch that controls the Tardis translation unit, Word Lord. Hex, now!
[OC]: Copy that.
No!
Yes. Ever get the feeling, people just don't understand you?
All right. Round one to you, Doctor. But let's make it the best out of three - three...
Speech speeded up, lots of languages, then slowed right down.
Happy chatter.
Oh, look at them. Huh. Politicians. You'd think they were the best of friends.
Yes, well, that's a shared brush with death and a few bottles of brandy for you. Maybe there's hope for them yet.
At the risk of being Thick Hex again, I'm still not sure I understand what happened. I mean, reversing the Tardis's translation unit killed...
Don't say his name!
Killed You-Know-Who.
Set to reverse, the Tardis began translating the words and even the thoughts of everyone in the Bunker into a language they couldn't understand.
Tell me about it. Like... soeaking in tongues?

As soon as it started, I reset the Bunker's computer system, deleting every recorded word. With no spoken language or even thought to support them, both You-Know-Who and his Cordis were forced to take refuge inside the only printed text within hundreds of miles.
Printed text?
The Bunker Protocol Guide.
Precisely.
Chapter One. The man stood frozen behind the page, his face twisted with anger, one palm pressed against...
Book slammed shut.
That's enough. One wrong word could let him out again.
Attention. Military troops have entered the base. Repeat. Military troops have entered the base.
That'll be the Cavalry.

I did a little tinkering with the Tardis translator. Everyone's memories of the Cordis joke and You- Know-Who's name have been left in Ancient Spenozian. Inconvenient for them, but it'll do until we get the book out of here.
That's be now, like?
Good idea.
Door opens.
All right, hands behind your heads! Nobody move!
Oh no.
Nobody move?
Doctor, my watch.
What time is it?
And those are point four five calibre weapons.
The Cordis engines.
The book, quickly. Oh, no, no, no, no, no, no.
What is it?
The pages.
They're all blank.
He's gone!
Theme tune.
Tardis door closes.
Shall I put the kettle on?
Yes. But coffee, I think. For a change.
The Tardis dematerialises.
